column1: Will North Macedonia announce that it has completed its census before 1 October 2021?
column6: ['Society', 'Non-US Politics']
https://popis2021.stat.gov.mk/Активности/ПОПИСОТ-ЗАВРШУВА/

Updating my previous forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1338124). Per the census' website, the census should be completed by now. Quoting from https://popis2021.stat.gov.mk/Activities/THE-CENSUS-IS-COMING-TO-AN-END/ "at 20:00 we will be able to announce that finally, after 20 years, the State Statistical Office has successfully carried out the largest statistical operation". It is currently well past 20:00 in Macedonia so the announcement is late, but I expect it may still come in time for the resolution of this question as Macedonians will be up in the morning by then. This tweet (https://twitter.com/popis2021/status/1443634094320070663) may also count as some form of announcement: "Huge thanks to everyone who participated in #Попис2021! Thank you to everyone who participated in the statistical operation and contributed to accurate data on our population!".

I'm going 50/50 because this question is so vague I've no idea how it's going to be interpreted. What exactly constitutes an announcement, and who can speak on behalf of North Macedonia? And why would a census conductor announce completing a census before the deadline for completing it?
According to the latest report from the Balkan news they should meet the deadline
https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&u=https://popis2021.stat.gov.mk/default.aspx "ПОПИСОТ ЗАВРШУВА" translates to "The Census is Over". Posted on September 30th.
This question needed more attention. It is after 5pm in North Macedonia and I see no official announcement.
Should have read the fine print. Actual release of data immaterial.
They may complete the census but I doubt they'd announce it on the same day it's due to be completed. But then, what exactly constitutes an announcement? Would ministerial self-promotion count?

If this is a political necessity for the NM government to get an opening to the EU, and they gave the starting and ending dates prior of the census, there is no impediment for the government to declare it done.
Who knows?
I found the article provided by @fisherdbus helpful: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1338549
“If the final figures, which should be announced before the year’s end” https://balkaninsight.com/2021/09/24/north-macedonia-census-takers-rush-to-complete-head-count/
Tough question. They may complete the census but, I doubt they'll immediately announce having done so. Then again, they may not complete the census but announce having done so regardless.
Who knows?

The question asks for a completion of the census and that the release of the data is immaterial. I am going to assume that the completion of the census means the end of counting and the collation and analysis is a later date (obviously). The latter is intended to be complete by the end of 2021. The State Statistical Office appears to be confident is completing the headcount by September 30th, 2021. Objections will probably be raised by maligned parties although according to UK reports census data is outdated before it is published and therefore only indicative. Based on their optimism and possible political pressure, I will suggest completion by the due date.

My prediction is based on the following factors. (i) The census is currently taking place and there is a belief that some of the problems associated with the 2011 census that was canceled have been mitigated e.g., political interference (https://www.aljazeera.com/features/2021/5/12/why-is-it-so-difficult-to-hold-a-census-in-north-macedonia), and some optimism that the census will be completed (https://balkaninsight.com/2021/09/24/north-macedonia-census-takers-rush-to-complete-head-count/). Things do seem to be going better than they were in 2011 as described by the article referenced in the question statement (https://www.balcanicaucaso.org/eng/Areas/North-Macedonia/Census-fails-in-Macedonia-105372). (ii) Whether the problems have truly been mitigated may not matter too much. Even if there are still problems, because those in charge of completing the census believe these problems have been mitigated, they may still announce that they have completed the census. Issues about the census may simply occur later, such as when the results are published (and potentially challenged). (iii) The census may be completed before October 1st, but the announcement may only happen on the 1st of October (which is still a business day) or later. However, if the population is indeed in the 1.5-1.8m range, with 1.3m people registered as of the 24th at a rate of 100k people per day (https://balkaninsight.com/2021/09/24/north-macedonia-census-takers-rush-to-complete-head-count/) then everyone could be registered before the 30th of September with enough time to spare for an announcement that can be pre-drafted and published with a click. I do expect that the number of people registered per day might start falling as the registration rate increases, but It's hard to estimate by how much. (iv) I am not sure whether there is the possibility of a legal delay to the completion of the census as I have not been able to find a copy of the actual decree. That said, this has not come up in any articles I have seen on the topic so I suspect that there isn't.
A week before the census is due to end on September 30, around 1.3 million people have registered, official figures showed.

As noted previously, the clarification stating that the completion must be ANNOUNCED by 9/30, not just completed, has complicated the matter substantially. As a result, continuing to track with consensus forecast, which is currently 33%.

Moving to 50 for two reasons, I am unsure as to whether or not by law it has to finish by 30th, ie maybe there are no contingencies for delays in the census law as voted for by the parliament, and even if there aren't, there remains the question as to when the announcement will be made?
So to resolve yes the Macedonian government has to announce that the census is complete on 30 sept, which is the same day it is due to complete.
1212339 21.09.2021 https://popis2021.stat.gov.mk/default.aspx

Despite everything, they are apparently on track to finish on time. I am still expecting the announcement to be made the day after at the earliest, but bumping up my forecast based on progress to date.

I'm reducing my forecast based on a technicality. The census is supposed to be completed on Sept. 30, meaning they probably won't announce the completion until the next day.

According to reports from Alfa TV, Apostol Simovski, who is the head of the State Statistical Office, declared that the census would be completed by the end of September. This census is one of the key demands from Brussels for North Macedonia to become an EU member. From a political perspective, the conclusion of the census could be declared at the end of September whether it is or not.
Increasing chance of yes, and watching for news... the win is only if it's "announced that it has completed"

This article provides good background. https://www.aljazeera.com/features/2021/5/12/why-is-it-so-difficult-to-hold-a-census-in-north-macedonia The census is currently underway, but it's still unclear if it will be completed on Sept 30th as planned. It's also unclear how politics will play into either withholding completed data or announcing incomplete data as complete. I'm having a hard time putting a number on this now that the odds have increased (given the start of the process). But, given the history of the topic, it's difficult to be too confident that they will finish. I'll just move to the "I have no idea" rate for now.
Timeline will be tight. But it sounds like the government is intent on making this happen by 9/30. https://balkaninsight.com/2021/09/03/north-macedonia-to-start-delayed-census-despite-covid-19-fears/

Not going down much; recruiting hasn't been postponed. In addition, the last time it was delayed, this was done with a legislative change, rather than by fiat. So I think that the census is still in theory on schedule. My gut also tells me that this is closer to 20% than to 15%. What I think is going on is that even if the forces that be are planning for it to be on schedule, planning fallacy is difficult to account for. September 4/5 is the date to watch out for.

North Macedonian’s problems over conducting a meaningful census stem from the friction over the ethnic groups and misapprehension of the potential results of the demographics. Given the importance of their percentage of the population and their resultant rights plus the effect of the diaspora has created mistrust in the Government. The initial phase commenced in March in registering people who have emigrated and now reside in other countries. According to the Governments guidelines concerning the timeline of conducting a census, the original census in April was to be completed 21 days. The completion by October 1st of the census would now appear to be in doubt. It has to be carried out eventually given the 20 year gap, the need to allocate resources and the requisites to join the EU, but possibly taking a little longer.

Nice link from @LokiOdinevich https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1324240 . Having trouble hiring census workers and applications still being accepted thru 8/25 originally scheduled to close 8/5. The enumeration was expected to start sept 5 and go to sept 30. I nad read it would take 3 weeks but they plan for 4. So with the delay in hiring workers and then tkme to get them trained it is going to be tight. I think if it doesn't start by sept 10 then it will not be completed by oct 1. So i will leave 10% that it gets done.
Admission of census workers has been delayed further, until August the 25th. https://popis2021.stat.gov.mk/%D0%90%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8/%D0%BC%D0%BA

Level 1: The census was cancelled Level 2: The census was only postponed, and its still due to happen by the end of September Level 3: Recruitment for census workers has been repeatedly delayed (first from the 5th of August to the 12th of August, then until the 17th), which suggests that the census as a whole also might be delayed. Consider also that the census workers have to be trained once they sign up, but I'm not sure how long that would take. Also, the pay for census workers is 40,000 Macedonian denari, or about 650€, which is less attractive than e.g., emigration.
Going back up to 30% on news reports. We will see.

North Macedonia prime minister says he has agreement with the opposition leader to hold the census. Currently, the census is scheduled to be completed by September 30th. https://www.dw.com/en/zoran-zaev-on-conflict-zone/av-58582668

The reports appear to indicate that the opposition to holding the census is not the issue of conducting the exercise, but the fear of an unwanted result or the possibility of using the outcome for political gains, rather than the altruistic intention of gaining relevant data to organise and distribute the country’s resources in an efficient manner. The main issue being the Macedonian majority and the ethnic Albanian minority that includes the diaspora that have emigrated in recent years where rights and privileges are tied to the community’s physical numbers. For instance, Arber Ademi who represents ethnic Albanians in the Democratic Union for Integration (DUI) has threatened to discount the results if the Albanian count is less than 20%. Conversely, a higher count, opposition claims a higher number of ethnic Albanians will give them more rights. They are concerned the census will show a higher number of ethnic Albanians than previously estimated, which could give them more rights (which is where the diaspora count comes in).

" 'The Europeanisation of the Macedonian society must not wait, and we expect our plan for the final processes for this agenda to bring us the same positive report for 2021,' Zaev pointed out." [...] "Zaev and Dimitrov said that the agenda in its implementation relies on the new EU enlargement methodology, while the emphasis, with specific tasks, relevant institutions and deadlines, is on electoral reform, the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime, fundamental human rights, media reform, economic governance and public administration reform." [...] "Zaev underlined that the plan was prepared by Dimitrov with the team from the Secretariat for European Affairs and in consultation with several ministries and that it is an agenda of the Government and other institutions such as the Parliament, judiciary, State Election Commission, the State Commission for Prevention of Corruption, as well as other agencies and commissions, which in cooperation with the Government, will complete the remaining activities for full Europeanisation of the system and their work according to EU standards as their benchmarks." https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2021/03/10/government-of-north-macedonia-adopts-europe-at-home-agenda/

If the census takers have to visit people and get as many as possible to respond then things light go on a while. Still think the gouvernement will announce a complete census, even if it’s not fully complete. Even if say there is a 30pc response rate it’s more data than they have at the moment and can be used statistically to assess the rest of the population. Which is really what they need. Anything is going to be better than the current position.

Opposition led by conservative VMRO-DPMNE insists that the process must be pushed back until 2022, citing the coronavirus pandemic and fears that the process will be rigged for political reasons. Asked about the possibility of postponement following the opposition pressure, the government press office said that the census will be held as scheduled. The government is convinced that North Macedonia will have a successful census. Bne IntelliNews talked to some people to take the pulse of the general opinion about the census and the most of them said that despite the opposition obstructions the government has launched the process and it is now a done deal.

https://www.intellinews.com/balkan-blog-census-sparks-a-political-storm-in-north-macedonia-204418/?source=blogs&utm_source=Newsletter&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=Edpicks BALKAN BLOG: Census sparks a political storm in North Macedonia BALKAN BLOG: Census sparks a political storm in North Macedonia In such a deeply divided society as North Macedonia even holding a census is not an easy thing to do. With the last census held 19 years ago — the previous attempt in 2011 was called off when it became mired in political infighting — no one knows exactly how many people live in North Macedonia. The government says they need an accurate count of the population to be able to draw up long-term development plans, not to mention provide facilities such as schools and medical care to the population efficiently. But the opposition wants the count postponed and is urging people not to open their doors to census takers.
There is talk of a boycott; going down slightly.

They have started the online survey for the diaspora community (http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/europe/2021-03/02/c_139776195.htm). I still think there is a decent chance their plan gets waylaid, but bumping my estimate up another 5%

Upgrading my forecast because a census bill passed parliament last week and the President has now signed it into law https://balkaneu.com/north-macedonia-pendarovski-signed-the-decree-for-the-census/. Census now scheduled for 1-21 April. The opposition party has said it won't recognise the results, suggesting it won't obstruct the census being carried out. Practical hurdles remain but there is a clear political will from the ruling party and the President to get this done.
It is necessary because of the upcoming Local Elections. Lot of prior arrangements must have been made, so this must be finished by then.

The recent vote in parliament calls for a census in April. (https://www.rferl.org/a/north-macedonia-census-albanians/31062243.html) The VMRO-DPMNE will likely attempt to prevent a census from occurring but North Macedonia has significant incentives to hold a census to move forward with the EU ascension process. While challenges remain, the completion of a census appears to be more likely than not by 1 October.

Complicated history with ethnic & religious factors with the 20% minority provisional rights of Albanians being a concern if they may lose through the census and concern about counting methods & the accuracy of counting (do you have to be present? can third parties speak on someone else's religious beliefs accurately). Much emigration and having fewer children has occurred so many are concerned about the political results/consequences. Relationship with Bulgaria is also a complicating factor with EU status.

North Macedonia is embroiled in complicated exchanges with Bulgaria surrounding history. Clearing this issue up is a hurdle to EU ascension. This distraction and potential outcomes of the census could complicate North Macedonia's long-term goal.
Party in government favors census, main opposition party opposes. Tie goes to party that controls levers of power?

Factors in favour: • Government has identified the census as a priority. President Stevo Pendarovski in October 2020: “It is absolutely crucial for the country to execute the census next year because no sound policies in any domain are possible without correct statistical data. At present, all vital statistics are based on estimations and that is not something any serious administration should be doing.” https://www.ft.com/content/5dafc7e1-d233-48c4-bd6b-90a2ed45a6e7 • It is crucial, if not a formal prerequisite, for North Macedonia’s accession to the EU • It has already been delayed once, the coalition government will be reluctant to delay again • Current plan is for an April census which allows a further six month delay for political and/or Covid-related reasons
Now that they are in the spotlight they won't mess this up

I found an academic article on the subject [1] that discusses the history of censuses and the census project for 2021. It is written by an academic of the State Statistical Office of North Macedonia. This article says: "The next census is scheduled for 2021, with reference date set for midnight 31 March. " The article describes the planned methodology, " a socially acceptable methodology "

Actually on second thoughts even not knowing the politics, conducting a divisive census that requires house to house visits during the Covid outbreak is madness, and is likely to be delayed again. If they delayed it once already for electoral reasons, delaying it a second time for health reasons should not be too controversial.

There appears to be enough political issues around conducting this census that Covid should be a face-saving excuse for everyone to delay it. But given how much I know about North Macedonian politics I struggle to answer this question in too binary a manner
At first glace it seems government reluctance may delay the census, but there has to be one eventually.
There are social pressure not to complete the census but also with COVID-19 still around there will be no reason to force it.
Unlikely to be a priority in a Covid impacted year
The latest info of North Macedonia's international relations, to the EU in particular, are described as follows:

The arguments amongst the political entities appear to be two-fold. Should absentee citizens be allowed to offer their data given that many (including families have vacated to Western Europe and if third parties are acting in proxy, is this valid? The second issue is the nature of the census and how the collected will be used. The Governments position is that the census is non-political, where the results will not affect the country’s constitution, but is refuted by the opposition that suspects political motives. ‘The Macedonian constitution provides for certain civil collective rights for ethnic communities when they represent over 20% of the population in a certain municipality or throughout the country’ The Albanian political parties are concerned by a loss of municipal rights if the census shows a figure of less than 20% due the absentees. North Macedonia has been implementing EU related reforms as a precursor to joining the European bloc and is showing progress in this regard including transparency in all governmental issues. This might help ease the frictions amongst the various ethnic segments of society. Fifty-Fifty at this point and under review.
Covid

It seems to me that it will most likely be necessary for North Macedonia to carry this census out at some point, since the number that they have from 2002 will increasingly be questionable, because they know that people continue to leave the country. It also appears to me as though they have no real motivation to actually carry this out right now, since it seems the gains are statistical accuracy while the downfalls are ethnic conflict and political conflict. Further it seems they have not ebgun the process yet, and so it might be hard to finish the count before October 1st if they do not soon start the preparations for initiating the census.
Little reason to believe that they will accomplish it.

I know nothing about North Macedonia. I'm only for casting this question cuz I like to forecast questions every now and then on something I don't know. The country has about 2 million maybe more people and it's obvious that the census gets hung up on how to count all the citizens who all migrated to other countries and I've been out of the country for more than 6 months. Since it's been so long since I've done the census, obviously a census in such a small country it's not that important. So it's not like North Macedonia will stop functioning if this doesn't happen which means the opposition will have a lot of room to oppose this. And currently the opposition is strong so they could easily postpone this again. It seems to me that whenever politicians face a politically very tough decision they tend to keep kicking the can down the road and I don't see why this can won't get kicked.

Given the numerous delays, there is impetus to complete the census. However, due to the legislation required for the headcount, and the current EU ascension talks, I will keep the Forecast on the side of yes, and update as required, especially around April 2021, which seems to be a date being given for the Census to begin.
